column1: Hormone therapy (HT) uses one or more hormones to treat symptoms of menopause.
HT uses estrogen, progestin (a type of progesterone), or both.

Estrogen comes in: - Nasal spray - Pills or tablets, taken by mouth - Skin gel - Skin patches, applied to the thigh or belly - Vaginal creams or vaginal tablets to help with dryness and pain with sexual intercourse - Vaginal ring Most women who take estrogen and who still have their uterus also need to take progestin.
Progesterone or progestin comes in: - Pills - Skin patches - Vaginal creams - Vaginal suppositories The type of HT your doctor prescribes may depend on what menopause symptoms you have.
Vaginal rings, creams, or tablets help relieve vaginal dryness.
Your doctor may prescribe other medicines if you have severe symptoms or have a high risk of osteoporosis.
